title: DS310.16 Term Modifier | DataStax Enterprise 6 Search
description:
#DataStaxAcademy #DS310
DS310.16 Term Modifier
In this section, we'll be taking a look at some other powerful searches that can be performed, many of these which will do not require an exact match, but rather can return results that are close, or similar to what you are searching for. We'll also be looking at a search that can prioritize certain terms to show up in the results.

LEARN FOR FREE at https://academy.datastax.com -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.

ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.

transcript.text: [Music] hello i'm joe chu and welcome to term modifiers in this video we'll be taking a look at some other powerful searches that can be performed many of these which do not require an exact match rather can return results that are close or similar to what you are searching for we'll also be looking at a search that can prioritize certain terms to show up in the results the first search we'll be discussing is the wild card search this is a way to find documents that have terms that matches a given pattern if you're coming from a relational database background this is very similar to the functionality of the like operator the way it works is by searching for a term using a wild card somewhere in the term either at the front the end or anywhere in between there are two types of wild cards the question mark which matches a single character and the asterix which matches zero or more characters in the examples below you have one wild card search that is looking for terms similar to question mark ast this matches terms like last for the last samurai fast for fast and furious and past such as in x-men days of future past the other example is searching for fr asterix d which matches framed fried and thread as seen in the resulting movie titles there are some things to note about wild card searches one being that they do not work with phrase searches another is that the text analysis used by field can affect how wild card searches matches for example using a text field and standard analyzer does not apply the same analysis chain to the search query so that search terms that are capitalized will not match the index terms that have been filtered to be all lowercase in this kind of situation the exact same wildcard search we used in the previous example would actually return zero results simply because the schema is different for the title field with buzzy search you can search for documents that have a term that is similar to the search term this kind of search can be enabled by adding a tilde at the end of a term and optionally adding a value of 1 or 2. this value represents the number of single character edits that would be needed to change the match term to the search term the example below shows a fuzzy search that will match terms similar to the term 7 the first result the magnificent 7 is an exact match the second term is a match because editing the number 7 in the term and changing it to a v return it into the search term the last result matches because the term even can be edited to add an s which could then match our search term besides replacing the character and adding a character the other possible way to edit the term would be to remove a character which unfortunately we do not have an example up here proximity search is somewhat like fuzzy search except that it searches for similar phrases instead of terms like a buzzy search a tilde is added at the end of a phrase to enable a proximity search an optional numeric value can specify the maximum distance the terms and the phrase can be apart from each other in example below there is a proximity search with an edit distance of three meaning that there can be at most three additional terms in between the original terms in the phrase if you have already seen the video on document scoring then you may be aware that it is possible to manually boost the score of documents that contains a specific term this can be done by adding a caret followed by a boost value at the end of a term in a search query aside from terms phrases and subqueries can also be boosted as well the example below shows a search query that looks for the word gosling or affleck in the description field with the word affleck being boosted by facult3 this may cause movies that contain the word app like in the description to show up in the search results before movies with the word gosling the last search that we'll be discussing here is the range search which matches all the values in a document field within a certain bound this is done with the syntax shown here where you can use square brackets or curly braces to specify a range search and then the values to be bound by where the asterisks can be used too it is important that the two in the range search is in capital letters because otherwise your search query will return an error in our example the range search uses the square bracket to look up all release years that includes 2000 up to 2015 with the curly brace being exclusive this return results for movies with release years between 2000 all the way up to 2014.
